sentences.sentence: By Keyli LoeppkyYou own a small family restaurant.
You should be out front greeting customers and helping your serving staff during the lunchtime rush, or busy in the kitchen coming up with new additions to your menu.
But you're not.

You're in the back office, filling out paperwork, jumping through hoops and trying to decode the government jargon across all the forms, permits and licences required to run your business.You are not alone.
This is the frustrating reality faced by hundreds of thousands of owners of small businesses(https://financialpost.com/category/entrepreneur/small-business/) all across Canada.
And governments just don't get it.

That is why 15 years ago the Canadian Federation of Independent Business (CFIB)(https://financialpost.com/tag/canadian-federation-of-independent-business/) introduced Red Tape Awareness Week: a campaign to draw governments' attention to how red tape(https://financialpost.com/opinion/fall-economic-statement-goodbye-red-tape-hello-green) slowly strangles many small businesses.A certain amount of regulation is necessary to ensure consumer, safety and environmental protection, but red tape is the excessive, duplicative, and unnecessary rule-making that gets in the way of living your life or running your business.

It is the byproduct of an unchecked government culture in which, year after year, regulations and processes pile up on each other with no follow-up effort to review and streamline them.Unfortunately, regulators are not the end-users of the regulations they create - and it shows.
Canadians are left to grapple with confusing government websites full of broken links, redundant forms, unnecessary reporting requirements and overly burdensome compliance standards.

It is not the impact of a single regulation that causes frustration, but rather the cumulative effect of all the rules imposed by all levels of government that weighs so heavily.The burden of regulation makes it difficult for firms to just get by, much less grow, innovate, and increase productivity.

According to CFIB, red tape costs businesses nearly $11 billion in time and expense each and every year, so it's not surprising that 92 per cent of Canadians say governments should make it a high priority to improve their service to the public.When CFIB first started Red Tape Awareness Week, very few governments in Canada were tracking and reporting their regulatory burden.

Such poor public accountability would never be accepted when it comes to taxes(https://financialpost.com/personal-finance/taxes/time-cra-implement-automatic-tax-filing-system) and government spending.
Imagine the scandal if governments refused to report on their finances.

But that was standard practice for regulation.Fifteen years later, we have seen some improvement in Canada's regulatory accountability, with most jurisdictions now at least tracking and reporting their burden.
Many also have constraints in place to keep the rule count in check.

Alberta and Ontario even have ministers dedicated to reducing the burden of red tape across government.So, despite all these improvements, why are business owners still spending their days in the back office?Measuring and reporting the regulatory burden are good first steps, but do not go far enough to make a difference on the ground.
Governments need to go further and reduce red tape to help address public policy challenges.
For example, the government of Nova Scotia has addressed critical health care challenges by fixing redundant and overly burdensome forms to free up physician time.

Improvements to the province's Income Assistance Medical Assessment form saved over 19,000 hours per year but also got support to those in need sooner.The runaway cost of government construction projects(https://financialpost.com/opinion/runaway-cost-government-construction-projects)Canada's decline into irrelevance(https://financialpost.com/opinion/swaggering-staggering-canada-decline-irrelevance)Canadians are overtaxed and underserved(https://financialpost.com/opinion/canadians-overtaxed-underserved)This is the type of low-cost action to make life easier that we need to see more of from governments.

To achieve it, politicians and policy-makers need to undergo a culture shift in which they are no longer motivated by how many rules they can impose but instead regulate only when regulation is absolutely necessary and focus more on streamlining and simplifying.When governments achieve this mindset shift, they not only reduce red tape and the regulatory burden but also strengthen their relationship with businesses and citizens.

The time is ripe to get Canada's business owners out of the back office and back to what they do best - running their business.Financial PostKeyli Loeppky is director of interprovincial affairs at the Canadian Federation of Independent Business.

Red Tape Awareness Week 2024, presented in partnership with Intuit QuickBooks, runs from Jan. 29 to Feb. 2.Bookmark our website and support our journalism: Don't miss the business news you need to know - add financialpost.com(https://financialpost.com/ ) to your bookmarks and sign up for our newsletters here(https://financialpost.com/newsletters/ ).
@COPYRIGHT=© 2024 Postmedia Network Inc. All rights reserved.

documents.result_message: Our detector is moderately confident that the text is written entirely by a human.
